column4: The basics

column1: Say what you mean, do what you say
column4: Be kind to your future self and only make commitments you can keep. Notice when you're not making commitments and re-evaluate which side is breaking down.
To meetings, to Zoom calls. Show up on time and let the person know if you're running late. Don't make it a habit.
Be kind and treat everyone with respect.
Who do you spend time with? They influence who you become.
Your actions define who you are and who you become. Think about your actions and habits.

column1: What you Do > Who you want to Be
column4: Think about what you enjoy doing and do that. Who you want to be is a dream. Do what you enjoy and you will become someone you like.

column5: These are the people who are fun to work with. Be solution oriented and make it happen.

column4: Perfect gets in the way of getting important answers. Create a tight deadline for a first cut and push it through. You'll cut corners but you can get something functional into the wild. You'll save a ton of time and assumptions and learn from the people you show it to.
You've only got one body

The Dalai Lama, when asked what surprised him most about humanity, answered 'Man! Because he sacrifices his health in order to make money. Then he sacrifices money to recuperate his health. And then he is so anxious about the future that he does not enjoy the present; the result being that he does not live in the present or the future; he lives as if he is never going to die, and then dies having never really lived.'
Focus on your breath and your five senses. Practice gratitude. Let go of things out of your control.
My typical response is Yes and have learned over time that saying No is a muscle that should be trained. No. is a complete sentence.
What drives other people?

column6: Once people are paid enough, money does not motivate. Once people are paid enough, they are motivated by autonomy, mastery of a skill, and purpose.

column4: Easy choices, hard life. Hard choices, easy life. Make the hard choices. Even when it's possible to punt. The inertia of mediocrity will not break unless you break it. What do you choose: Short term pain, long term gain or short term delay, long term pain?

column1: People perceive things in different ways
column4: You can't assume what someone else is thinking. Don't make assumptions -> ask questions.
How to look at things.
People see successful outcomes and call others lucky ignoring all of the failures along the way.
People look to connect outcomes after they happen. Be yourself and do what you want. They can use the same trait to describe something good or bad that happens. Who cares what they think.
Everyone's world resolves around them. Look out for yourself, don't worry about what other people think about you, and try not to be shaped by other peoples expectations. This is your life.
Decisions you make today are small in the eyes of your 80 year old self. Making significant decisions from that view will help you avoid living with regret.
Not wasting time
Pick 2. It's hard to balance all three. Think about the trade offs when you make decisions.

If each part you build is rock solid then when things break, you know where you don’t need to look first. Accepting that there will be unexpected behavior with systems, code, organizations, or products helps to be ready for problem solving when they happen. When you’re troubleshooting with a clear head it’s easier to debug in smarter ways, like not checking 'solid building blocks' first.
It's easy to make emotional decisions. Try to be fact based. Write them down and weigh trade offs. This takes practice but is a skill you can hone.
If it can't be built quickly it's too complicated. How do you manage process / features out? A team with a simple process can go far.

column1: Don't let long term planning distract
column4: Long term planning can distract from doing important work today.

column1: What you use > what you know
column4: "Ideas are only helpful if they're put into practice. I think it's important to re-visit the things you learn and hard lessons to make sure you remember them and can continue to learn from them and put them into practice."
